prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 2-1 mapping of main bridge regions and knots
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This provides a partial masaic of the critical bridge regions in CO (2-1). The depth is such that it probes down the some of the fainter structures seen in the PdB map but at much higher resolution and in this brighter line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We would like a minimum of 10 km/s resolution, and to allow som flexibility if the source is stronger than expected, we have spectrally averged only by a factor of 4 to reduce data rate. We need a reasonably broad bandwidth for the line over the full ~2GHz.
We observe three bands to get 2 continuum measurements.

We want to probe down to angular scales of GMCs, 0.2 arcsec is 60 pc at distance of Taffy (62Mpc) and is ideal for identifying GMCs and associations on these scales and coherent motions within complexes (Shear/Rotation/turbulent motions).
We are primarily targeting gas in the bright knots and extended ridge, although we cover some other areas where diffuse gas exists. Does the structure of these clouds differ from those in the denser part of the bridge? Are there coherent strcutures forming around the star formation sites? Since it is possible some of the emission is extended we want to be able to recover structure up to 10 arcsecs in the galaxies. (Large thin structures are seen --for example in the Antenna galaxies--We would want to be able to not overrolve similar structures. )

Sensitivity:
Based on JCMT observations of the Taffy Bridge by Zho et al. (2003) the ratio of brightness temperatures r_21 = 0.79, (CO2-1/CO1-0), and therefore we expect the flux density ratio between CO(2-1)/ CO(1-0) to be r_21*(Nu_230/Nu_115)^2 = 3.16. CO2-1 should be 3.16 X brighter than CO 1-0 in flux density units.
The knots in the Taffy system have CO 1-0 fluxes in the range 1.5-10 Jy/beam * km/s based on a 2.9 x 2.6 PdB interferometer beam, over a velocity range ~ 200 km/s. The emission is quite compact and we assume the actual clump scale is ~ 0.5 x 0.5 arcsecs^2 in extent, or 25 0.2 x 0.2 ALMA beams. The expected CO (2-1) flux density for the fainter features in a bandwidth of 10 km/s = 9.5 mJy/beam, and brighter for the brighter regions. Smoothing our native channels to 10 km/s we can achieve an rms of 1.5 mJy/beam in fainter structures in 1.65 hrs. This would correspond to a detection of the fainter Taffy ridge at a S/N of 6 and the brighter knots at a S/N of > 20. The small mosaic of 9 beams is perfect to hit the main ridges of emission and even covers the northern galaxy which will be much brighter. Our integration time is limited by the faintest structures. We particularly want to explore fainter emission in both the souther ridge and across the denser molecular/HI boundry (see proposal).
This is the only band that could be performed, in principal, with PdB in the future. Assuming 6km/s resolution velocity resolution it would take 37hrs to get to an rms of 1.5 mJy/0.2arcsec beam. We would need to do 12 pointings in a mosaic and it would take 400 hrs. Given that we want to match resolutions with our other bands, this would seem an unlikely path to take.
Velocity resolution
For the brighter clumps we may be able to get better velocity resolution than 10 km/s (our default width). The lines in the bridge are of the order of 200 km/s in a large beam, and so we would like 20 elements across this, or more depending on sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 bridge mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A mosaic of 7 beams at CO (3-2) including HCO+ in the upper sideband and I am attempting to shift the central Lo so that CS 7-6 falls in the band

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have attempted to capture not only CO 3-2 (LSB) but also the HCO+ line (USB) and if we can tweak the LO setting slightly, the CS 7-6 line at edge of LSB, otherwise this third band will act as continuum. We have chosen to reduce the data rate by smoothing to 6 km/s.

We want matched angular scales for our LVG excitation analysis (so 0.2 arcsecs or 60 pc at Taffy). As in the other bands we wish to capture any extended flux if present so we chose 9 arcsec for the largest angular size.

We use the PdB CO (1-0) map as the basis of our predicted CO(3-2) signal strength and target both the brighter knots (at 8-10y * km/s) and fainter features at 1.5-2 Jy*km/s. Based on the observed r3-1 brightness temperature ratio for the bridge as a whole given by Zhu et al (2003) of 0.44 and converting to flux density we expect the CO(3-2) to be a factor of 4 x brighter than the CO(1-0) line. (It is difficult to directly calculate the CO (3-2) flux from the JCMT measurements quoted by Zhu et al. because of the huge beam-size, but the numbers we derive, summing over the knots are approximately consistent). For a 10 km/s linewidth and a clumping scale of 0.5 x 0.5 arcsecs (which we assume is spread evenly over 7 ALMA 0.2 x 0.2 arcsec beams) we expect the signal in one beam to be 7-28 mJy/beam. the S/N ratio at an rms of 1.35 mJy/beam is between 5 and 20 for the fainter and brighter knots. As before, the bandwidth of 1.87GHz with small channels that we will later smooth to 10 km/s. The width of the line emission is of the order 200 km/s, and this might extend to small scales since this is a highly shocked system.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 6-5 Two fields centered on brightest molecular knots

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will smooth the data to 10 km/s. We have staggered three bands around the line center (offset the satallite bands by 1GHz on either side of the expected line velocity) to ensure we have a broad enough coverage of the galaxy in case we need it. We will smooth the data to as large a value as possible to reduce data rates.

At 0.2 arcsecs resolution the linear resolution on the target (62 Mpc) is 60pc, the scale of GMC complexes. The clumps could-in principal sit in a larger envelope of gas and so we request 4.7 arcsec as the LAS.

Following the argument for the other lines, the target signal in a 10 km/s bandwidth is 150mJy. (S/N = 10). Working backwards, as before we assume the line strength in CO (6-5) is 20 x the signal strength at CO 1-0 (based on models of a 150K gas and density of 10^3.(the temperature and density of the warm H2 found in the bridge with out Spitzer observations (Peterson et al. 2012).
We two target CO clumps in the CO(1-0) PdB map are ~ 8Jy/bm* km/s over 200 km/s, or 400mJy/PdB bm in 10 km/s. Assuming the emission is uniformly spread over 0.5 x 0.5 arcsec scale, we estimate the CO 1-0 in a 0.2 x 0.2 arcsec beam is 16mJy/alma beam. The CO (6-5) flux should be at least 20* brighter than the CO (1-0) line based on models of mildly shock heated gas (it may be more). We will assume CO (6-5) = 20* CO(1-0) in flux density so the total per 0.2 x 0.2 arcsec beam is 320 mJy/alma beam. Our observation will yield an rms noise of 15mJy/bm so the S/N in the line at 10 km/s should be ~ 20.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO 2-1 single observation on brightest sources only
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: To provide a rough estimate on the brightest sources on the opacity we need a dedicate observation. I placed the 4 bright knots at the center of the primary beam.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: I have set the correlator to collect data in 10 km/s channels with spectral averaging
Matched to previous observations at 0.2 arcsecs to get down to 60pc--

Since at this redshift it is not possible to get 13CO in the same band as the main 12CO 2-1 mapping, instead I target ONLY the brightest sources and go 10x deeper than 12CO in one single beam. This will provide us with some constraints on the modeling of the excitation (see 2-1 mapping). It is too expensive to do this for the full field.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map CO emission in the highly turbulent molecular bridge stretching between the Taffy galaxies (UGC 12914/5) in three CO transitions with matched resolution. The bridge is believed to have formed when two gas-rich disk galaxies recently collided almost head-on, creating a massive molecular bridge. There is strong evidence from our multi-wavelength data that the bridge contains warm gas turbulently and shock heated which is now beginning to cool. A powerful ridge of molecular gas contains clumps of H$_2$, but not all the clumps are forming stars. We plan to, a) map most of the bridge in CO(2-1), including across the molecular/diffuse gas transition seen in Herschel C+, HI, and X-rays , b) explore how the thermal properties of the gas changes in the densest regions for star forming, and non-star forming clumps, and c) investigate the nature of molecular gas down to 60pc (GMC-association) scales to explore whether some of the clouds are limited by turbulent shear, or are collapsing. The observations will provide insight into the importance of turbulence in suppressing star formation in galaxy evolution.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
